sn18.11:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.
sn18.11:1.3: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
sn18.11:1.5: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn18.11:1.7: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.11:1.9: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.11:1.10: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.11:1.16: Is the mind permanent or impermanent?”
sn18.11:1.18: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn18.11:1.20: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn18.11:1.21: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn18.11:1.23: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, the ear, the nose, the tongue, the body, and the mind.
sn18.11:1.24: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn18.11:1.25: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn18.11:1.26: (The ten discourses of this series should be treated in the same way.)
